title: Lamar AD's swift exit leaves questions
title_page: Lamar AD's swift exit leaves questions
maintext:
Without forewarning or explanation, Jason Henderson is no longer Lamar University’s athletic director, after more than five years on the job.
Henderson briefly gathered the Lamar athletic staff Monday morning to announce he was leaving the position he held since June 2012, according to Lamar sports information director James Dixon.
Attempts to reach Henderson for comment were unsuccessful.
Lamar released a statement Monday naming Norman Bellard as the school’s interim athletic director.
The statement made no mention of Henderson’s departure, and his biography has been removed from the Lamar athletic website.
“Norman Bellard’s involvement with Lamar University, as a student-athlete, distinguished alumnus, Cardinals fan, and as a long-standing member of our staff, makes him uniquely qualified to serve as interim Athletic Director,” Lamar University President Kenneth Evans said in the statement. “We look forward to his leadership and vision as we move forward at this moment of unprecedented opportunities for Lamar University athletics.”
No timetable was given for hiring Henderson’s replacement, but according to the statement, “a full national search will begin immediately.”
The move came less than 24 hours after Henderson, 38, attended Sunday’s Lamar
men’s basketball game against Cal State-Bakersfield.
Henderson, in his 11th year with the school, was named Lamar’s interim athletic director in 2011 before officially taking over in June 2012.
Non-revenue sports, like cross country, women’s golf and men’s tennis, saw sustained success during Henderson’s tenure.
The school’s bigger sports - notably football and men’s basketball -struggled.
Average attendance at football games dropped from 11,000 in 2012 to 6,600 this season.
Lamar football on Saturday finished its worst season (2-9) since the program’s 2010 rebirth.
Men’s basketball hasn’t made the NCAA Tournament since the 2011-12 season.
Billy Tubbs, who preceded Henderson as Lamar’s athletic director, said he was surprised when he found out Henderson was no longer with the university.
“Something I’ve learned is that all good athletic directors are winning lots of games,” Tubbs said. “It’s a tough ask and it’s hard to satisfy everybody, but I had no idea this was going to happen.”
Henderson made $129,530 during the 2017 year.
Bellard has been with Lamar since 2015 as the assistant to the president for community relations and athletics program liaison.
He will continue that role in addition to his new duties.
“My primary goal will be to continue to put a quality product on the fields and courts that is attractive to the community, both on campus and beyond,” Bellard said in the statement.
